assign.name: Create Your Own Number Talk
assign.intro:
For this activity, you will create a number talk that you will use with your adult learners.

When you create a number talk, select a problem in which the numbers and operations will encourage different ways of seeing—for example, a problem that can be solved in several ways—so that learners can share their thinking and approaches. You want to ensure that the problem you select will produce a rich discussion from your learners. If you want to use a numerical expression for your first number talk, Humphreys and Parker (2015) suggest using a subtraction problem.

Note: You may choose to do a dot talk, a type of number talk where, instead of numbers, you use an image with dots. (You will experience dot talks in Module 4.) Here are some resources about dot talks:

  • Atlas ABE Math Teacher Workout Let’s Talk About Dots!—particularly note the link to a video of Jo Boaler from Stanford University facilitating a dot talk with middle school students.
  • Number Talks website from the Math Perspectives Teacher Development Center. You may download the Arrangement Cards PDF files to use for a dot talk.

Assignment:

  1. Select a number talk problem (e.g., an expression like 53 − 18 or 11 × 39) that will lend itself to a rich discussion of learner thinking and sharing different approaches.
  2. Anticipate as many solutions as you can to your selected number talk problem.
    • Record your anticipated solutions for the number talk problem.
    • Practice how you will annotate these solutions if a learner shares one of your anticipated solutions.
    • Write down the questions you want to pose for learners to help them share and unpack their thinking. (It might be helpful to write some of these questions down alongside your anticipated solutions.)
  3. Compile the following in a document:
    • The problem you selected and why you think this is a good number talk problem for your learners
    • Two or three of your anticipated solutions
    • The preparation steps for your number talk (e.g., put pencils and paper away, fists on chest, thumb and fingers indicating solutions, etc.)
    • Four questions you plan to use during the number talk (e.g., questions to start the whole group discussion, to unpack a learner’s thinking, or to have a learner explain someone else’s thinking)
    • The Standards for Mathematical Practice you anticipate learners will engage in during the number talk
  4. Click the ADD SUBMISSION button below to upload the document you created in Step 3 about your number talk. Remember to click SAVE CHANGES, then click SUBMIT ASSIGNMENT when you are done.
  5. Implement this number talk activity with your learners and capture notes and thoughts on the experience. You will have the opportunity to share your experience implementing a number talk during Session 3.3.
  6. Optional: Repeat the steps above for a second number talk activity.
